Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Wushi Goldring is "Exploring the Limits of Algebraicity across Limits of Discrete Series, Galois Representations, and Variations of Hodge Structures." In the first year, the host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Christopher Skinner. POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI's project explored the limits of algebraicity in the Langlands Program for number fields. This led to a new program, joint with Jean-Stefan Koskivirta (see below).


While automorphic representations are initially defined by analytic methods, the Langlands Program predicts that a distinguished subset of them satisfies deep algebraic properties. One of these properties is that certain numbers associated to the representation -- known as Hecke eigenvalues -- are algebraic numbers i.e. satisfy a polynomial equation with rational coefficients. Another is the existence of an associated family of Galois representations. The PI's project was concerned with the case when the archimedean component of the automorphic representation is irregular. One reason this case is interesting is that, as the archimedean component moves farther from being regular, the relationship of the automorphic reprensetation with algebraic geomety becomes more and more mysterious. In many cases no relation is known at all.

The PI achieved four goals during the report submission period. Three concerned studying the algebraicity of automorphic representations via the coherent cohomology of Shimura varieties. The fourth regarded using Langlands functoriality to reduce the study of automorphic representations which do not appear in cohomology to that of those which do.

First, the PI's thesis about the case when the archimedean component is a holomorphic limits of discrete series was published. Second, the results about holomorphic limits of discrete series were significantly improved in joint work with Marc-Hubert Nicole. In this joint work we also gave the first general construction of a Hasse invariant whose nonvanishing locus is not the usual ordinary locus. Many further constructions of generalized Hasse invariants followed, both by the PI and by other authors.

Third, in joint work with  Jean-Stefan Koskivirta, we associated Galois representations to the coherent cohomology of Shimura varieties, both with torsion coefficients and with characteristic zero coefficients. As a result, we were able to treat the case of automorphic representations with general non-degenerate limit of discrete series representations.

The joint work with Koskivirta also established several important results in the theory of G-Zips and of Shimura varieties of Hodge type in characteristic p. The main constructiion in this work was that of group-theoretical Hasse invariants. These offer a generalization and group-theoretical reinterpretation of the classical Hasse invariant in two directions. The first direction is that the Hasse invariants are constructed on the stack of G-Zips rather than on a Shimura variety. This idea was already introduced in the work of Koskivirta and Wedhorn. By pull-back one obtains Hasse invariants on Shimura varieties.  However, our construction can similarly be pulled-back to any other scheme which admits a morphism to the stack of G-Zips. We are currently pursuing this exciting new direction.

The second way in which our work offers a significant generalization of all previous works on Hasse invariants is that we treat all strata closures of the zip stratification. By pull-back we obtain a Hasse invariant on every stratum closure of the Ekedahl-Oort stratification for every Shimura variety of Hodge type at a prime of good reduction.

We obtain two consequences about the geometry of these stratifications: First, we prove that both stratifications are principally pure. Second, we show that the Ekedahl-Oort strata of a Hodge-type Shimura variety are affine when suitably extended to the minimal compactification of the Shimura variey.

Perhaps more important than these concrete results, the PI's joint work with Koskivirta launched a program, motivated by a geometry-by-groups philosophy, of studying the interconnections between four different areas: (A) Algebraicity of automorphic representations, (B) The Deligne-Serre “interchange of characteristic” approach to algebraicity, concerning both (A), but also a host of other questions. (C) The geometry of stacks of G-Zips, the Ekedahl-Oort (EO) stratification of Shimura varieties and their Hasse invariants. (D) Algebraicity of Griffiths-Schmid manifolds.

 We have already produced three other joint papers with Koskivirta, as well as work in progress with Benoit Stroh and Yohan Brunebarbe, that further develop our program.

Finally we come to the fourth avenue pursued by the PI concerning algebraicity of automorphic representations. The idea here is to study to what extent Langlands functoriality can be used to prove algebraicity of automorphic representations. To this end, the PI refined and generalized previously studied classes of representations to obtain a hierarchy of representations modelled on their connections with algebraic geometry.The PI gave the first example of an irregular representation which is not a non-degenerate limit of discrete series and which maps, via functoriality, to one that is. This exhibits a new case of algebraicity, conditional on a special case of functoriality. This result was announced in talks in several places, including Paris, U. of Utah, Zurich and Stockholm. Fitting this example in a general framework is the focus of current work by the PI.
